_header: Gift is made doomsman / guile is made chapman
Note:
Ringler Jr. (1992)
XRingler Jr., William A. Bibliography and Index of English Verse in Manuscript 1501-1558. London: Mansell, 1992; prepared and completed by Michael Rudick and Susan J. Ringler , TM 463; this does not follow the Latin version, however, but the Gesta Romanorum — see Herrtage (1879)
XHerrtage, Sidney John Hervon. The Early English Version of the Gesta Romanorum.
EETS e.s. 33 (1879); repr. 1962, 360; cf. 3384, 3492, 4480
Bibliographic Ghosts:
Oxford, Bodleian Library Digby 53 (SC 1654), f. 55; see 3492; Oxford, Merton College Lat. 248, f. 120rb (cited in Brown (1939)
XBrown, Carleton Fairchild. Religious Lyrics of the XVth Century. Oxford: Clarendon, 1939, 345-6, 268).
_description: The Abuses of the Age — sixteen short lines with Latin couplets interspersed

BodAsh750.Last Lines:
…The deed is out of myndeand freend may no man
                    fynde
BodAsh750.Note:
Twelve lines, written two lines of verse per line of MS; preceded by
                    Latin version.

Bod797.First Lines:
Wytt is torned to trecherieLoue is torned to
                    lecherie…
Bod797.Last Lines:
…Lordes be wiþ outr laweAnd children ben wiþ outen
                    awe
Bod797.Note:
Variant copy of 7 lines: the second couplet lacks the second line; the
                    scribe left space for this line but did not copy it.

BodDou95.First Lines: Yifte is domesmanAnd gyle is Chapman…
BodDou95.Last Lines:
…The dede is oute of myndeand frendes may non
                    fynde
BodDou95.Note:
Sixteen lines (not just four as in Brown  and  Robbins (1943)
XCarleton Fairchild Brown,   and  Rossell Hope Robbins.  
             The Index of Middle English Verse.
         New York: Printed for the Index Society by Columbia University Press,
            1943); English
                    verses alternate with Latin.

Herrtage,  Sidney John Hervon,
                        ed.  
             The Early English Version of the Gesta Romanorum.
EETS
         e.s. 33 (1879); repr. 1962: 500, 360.

BodLauMis748.Transcription:
Wyse men beth blindekenrede ys vnkyndedeth ys out of mendeA
                    ffrend ys hard to fynde

CamStJohn37.First Lines: Ȝeft is domus man& gyle is chapman…
CamStJohn37.Note:
Sixteen short lines written two lines of text per line of MS; plus six
                    additional lines this MS after a two-line Latin interruption.
CamStJohn37.Editions:
Robbins,  Rossell Hope,
                        ed.  
             Historical Poems of the XIV and XV Centuries.
         New York: Columbia UP, 1959: 143-4, 326-7.

CamTCC1157.First Lines:
Oldmen ben scornyd Women arn wowedRichemen arn glosed and pouere
                    men bowed…
CamTCC1157.Last Lines:
…Wysemen arn blynde kynesby kynesmen beth
                    vnkyndeThe dede is out of mynd & ffrendes may noone fynde
CamTCC1157.Note:
Missing lines 1-4; 2 four-line stanzas with each English couplet
                    preceeded by Latin equivalent.
CamTCC1157.Editions:
Robbins,  Rossell Hope,
                        ed.  
             Historical Poems of the XIV and XV Centuries.
         New York: Columbia UP, 1959: 143-4, 326-7.

BLAdd8151.Last Lines:
…Ande euere in weele & in wooþenke one þe ioy
                    þat lasteþe for oo

Furnivall,  Frederick James,

gifte is domesman and gile is chapmanthe grete hold no lawe and
                    seruantes have none awe…

BLAdd60577.First Lines:
Wyt ys trecheryluff ys lecheryplay ys vylonyand holyday
                    ys glotony…wysse men are blynd& kynnysmen are vnkyndedethe
                    us oute of myndeand frende can no man fynde…
BLAdd60577.Last Lines:
…Gyfte ys Iugemanand gyle ys chapmanlordys haue no
                    lawenor chyldurn haue noo awe
BLAdd60577.Note:
Three four-line stanzas translating corresponding Latin which follows
                    each stanza.
BLAdd60577.Editions:
Wilson,  Edward. 
             “Introduction.” 
             The Winchester Anthology. A Facsimile of British Library Additional
                Manuscript 60577. With an account of the music by 
                    Iain
                    Fenlon. 
         Cambridge: D. S. Brewer, 1981.

BLHar2251.First Lines: Yift is made domesmanGyle is made chapman…
BLHar2251.Last Lines:
…The dede is out of myndeTriew friende can noman
                    fynde
BLHar2251.Editions:
Brown,  Carleton Fairchild,
                        ed.

BLHar3362.First Lines: Ȝyft ys domysmangyle ys ymakyd ȝeman…
BLHar3362.Last Lines: …Ȝe ded hys out of myndne frynd ne may man fynd
BLHar3362.Note: Written two lines of verse per line of manuscript.
BLHar3362.Editions:
Holmstedt,  Gustaf,
                        ed.  
             Speculum Christiani.
EETS
         o.s. 182 (1933); repr. 1988: clxxxvii.

BLRoy17Bxvii.First Lines:
Gift is domes mon gyle is chapmanLerdus be laules childer bene
                    awleys…
BLRoy17Bxvii.Last Lines: …Cosens ben vnkyndA gode syker frend is…
BLRoy17Bxvii.Note:
Lines 1-10. Two verse lines per manuscript line. Damage to
                    manuscript.

WestmAb27.Transcription:
wise men ben but scorned[?][three unreadable lines]lordes wex
                    euer blyndfrendes ben vnkyndedethe is out of myndeTreuth may
                    noman fynd
WestmAb27.Editions:
Peter,  John Desmond. 
             Complaint and Satire in Early English Literature.
         Oxford: Clarendon, 1956: 68.

RylandsLat394.Transcription:
Þere childe is kynge& clerke bysshopAnd chorle
                    reueall is greue
RylandsLat394.Note:
Variant; 4 lines written as two, translating the Latin Quando puer
                        regnat… which follows.
RylandsLat394.Editions:
Pantin,  William A. 
             “A Medieval Collection of Latin and English Proverbs…from Rylands
                Latin MS. 394.” 
             Bulletin of the John Rylands Library
         14 (1930): 81-114: 102.

Norwich158926.Last Lines:
…Deth is owt of mynde& treuþe may no man
                    fynde
Norwich158926.Note:
Wooden boards, four thongs, two clasps, following lengthy Latin preamble
                    in rubric, then primus dixit before first 2 couplets, etc.

WorcF154.First Lines: Ȝifte hys mad domesmongyle is mad chapmon…
WorcF154.Last Lines:
…Þe dede is out of myndefrend ne may non
                    fynde
WorcF154.Note:
Folio formerly foliated 102va; 8 couplets written as verse,
                    two lines of verse per line in the MS.
WorcF154.Editions:
Brown,  Carleton Fairchild. 
             “The ‘Pride of Life’ and the ‘Twelve
                Abuses.’” 
             Archiv für das Studium der neueren Sprachen und
                Literaturen
         128 (1912): 72-8: 76.
Floyer,  John Kestell,  and  Sidney Graves Hamilton.  
             Catalogue of Manuscripts Preserved in the Chapter Library of Worcester
                Cathedral.
         Oxford: for the Worcester Historical Society, by James Parker,
            1906: 85.

TCD509.First Lines: Yifte is domesmanand gyle is chapman…
TCD509.Last Lines:
…The dede is oute of myndeand frendes may none
                    fynd
TCD509.Note:
Each stanza written as two lines, immediately following the Latin
                    equivalent.
TCD509.Attributed Title:
In porta Orientali primus philosophus hos scriptsit versus (p. 7),
                    etc.

TCD517.First Lines:
Wyt ys turnyd to trecheryeand loue ys turnyd to
                    lecherye…
TCD517.Last Lines:
…Lordys haue non lawene chyldryn haue non haweNon est
                        lex dominis nec timor est pueris
TCD517.Note:
Stanzas re-arranged; four couplets written as two lines verse to one
                    line with Latin equivalents after each couplet.

TokyoTak61.First Lines:
Yift is domesman and gile is Chapmanlordes haue noo lawe ne
                    children haue none awe…
TokyoTak61.Last Lines:
…wysemen ar blynd kynesmen ar vnkyndThe dede is oute of mynd
                    & frendes may non fynd
TokyoTak61.Note:
Possibly same as Beaminster, Dorset,  J. Stevens Cox [olim Harmsworth; Sotheby Sale, Oct., 1945, lot 1956], now privately
            owned (see above). Lines mixed with Latin
                    verses on same subject; two lines of Latin precede this first line
